Expectation1: Take scheduled breaks and adhere to work hours
Situation1: The call volume is light, and supervisors allow flexible timing for breaks.
Situation2: There is a plan to have a quiet ten-minute window.
Story:
I glance at the clock on my monitor—ten minutes until my scheduled break. The call queue is almost empty, and my supervisor has just sent a message: “Feel free to take your break early if you want.” My body aches for a pause, but my mind is already elsewhere. I’ve been looking forward to this window all morning, a rare chance to sit quietly and practice mindfulness, to let the noise of the day settle and my breath guide me back to center.

But as I hover over the “log out” button, a new call pops up. I hesitate. The telemarketer in me knows the expectation: stick to the schedule, but also be flexible, keep the calls moving, don’t let the queue build up. The Buddhist in me feels the tug of commitment to my practice, the promise I made to myself to honor this ten-minute sanctuary.

My heart pounds with the pressure of these two worlds. If I take the call, I betray my intention for mindfulness. If I log out, I risk letting down my team. I sit, torn, the phone ringing, my breath shallow, caught between duty and devotion.
